questions.text: A recurrent chalazion should be subjected to histopathological examination to rule out the possibility of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sebaceous cell Ca Chalazion, also called a tarsal or meibomian cyst, is a chronic non-infective (non-suppurative) lipo granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland. This is the commonest of all lid lumps. Aetiology Predisposing factors are similar to hordeolum externum. Pathogenesis - Usually, first, there occurs mild-grade infection of the meibomian gland by organisms of very low virulence. As a result, there occurs proliferation of the epithelium and infiltration of the walls of the ducts, which are blocked. Consequently, there occurs retention of secretions (sebum) in the gland, causing its enlargement. The pent-up and extravasated secretions (fatty in nature) act like an irritant and excite non-infective lipo granulomatous inflammation of the blocked meibomian glands and surrounding tissue.

Highyeild:

Clinical features Symptoms include: Painless swelling Mild heaviness in the lid. Blurred vision may occur occasionally due to induced astigmatism by a very large chalazion pressing on the cornea. Watering (epiphora) may occur sometimes due to the eversion of the lower punctum. Signs include: Nodule Reddish purple area, A projection of the main bulk of the swelling on the skin side may be seen Marginal chalazion, occurring occasionally, may present as a small reddish-grey nodule on the lid margin.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: D. BCC is the most common human malignancy and typically affects older individuals. The most important risk factors are fair skin, inability to tan and chronic exposure to sunlight. Ninety per cent of cases occur in the head and neck and about 10 percent of these involve the eyelid. BCC is by far the most common malignant eyelid tumour , accounting for 90 per cent of all cases. It most frequently arises from the lower eyelid, followed in relative frequency by the medial canthus, upper eyelid and lateral canthus. Option: A. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is a much less common, but typically more aggressive tumour than BCC, with metastasis to regional lymph nodes in about 20 percent of cases. Histopathology shows dysplastic changes throughout the thickness of the epidermis. Careful surveillance of regional lymph nodes is therefore an important aspect of initial management. The tumour may also exhibit perineural spread to the intracranial cavity via the orbit . Option: C. Melanoma rarely develops on the eyelids but is potentially lethal . Although pigmentation is a hallmark of skin melanomas , half of lid melanomas are non-pigmented and this may give rise to diagnostic difficulty.

Extraedge:

Clinical course and complications Complete spontaneous resolution may occur rarely. The slow increase in size Fungating mass of granulation tissue may be formed occasionally when the lesion bursts on the conjunctival side. Secondary infection may lead to the formation of the hordeolum internum. Calcification may occur, Malignant change into meibomian gland adenocarcinoma (sebaceous cell carcinoma) may be seen occasionally in elderly people.

questions.text: A 76-year-old male patient came in for an annual checkup and was referred to the ophthalmology department due to the presence of bilateral yellowish subcutaneous plaques on the medial aspects of the eyelids. The family medicine resident reported that the patient had hyperlipidemia and was started on statins last week. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Xanthelasma The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Xanthelasma. Xanthelasma is a common , frequently bilateral condition typically affecting middle-aged and elderly individuals. Hyperlipidaemia is found in about one-third of patients, in whom corneal arcus may also be present. In contrast to a chalazion, fat in xanthelasma is mainly intracellular, with lipid-laden histiocytes (foam cells) in the dermis .

Highyeild:

Xanthelasma are yellowish subcutaneous plaques, usually in the medial aspects of the eyelids, commonly bilateral and are multiple

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Milia are caused by occlusion of pilosebaceous units resulting in the retention of keratin. They are tiny, white, round, superficial papules that tend to occur in crops. Option: B. Epidermal inclusion cyst is usually caused by implantation of the epidermis into the dermis following trauma or surgery It is a slow-growing, round, firm, superficial or subcutaneous lesion containing keratin. Option: C. A chalazion is a sterile chronic granulomatous inflammatory lesion (lipogranuloma) of the meibomian, or sometimes Zeis glands caused by retained sebaceous secretions. Histopathology shows a lipo granulomatous chronic inflammatory picture with extracellular fat deposits surrounded by lipid-laden epithelioid cells, multinucleated giant cells and lymphocytes. Blepharitis is commonly present; rosacea can be associated with multiple and recurrent chalazia.

Extraedge:

Management Simple excision is commonly performed where adequate excess skin is present. Microdissection: Larger lesions can be raised in a flap, the fatty deposits dissected from overlying skin under a surgical microscope using micro scissors and the skin replaced.

They are frequently numerous. Option: C. Actinic keratosis: Histopathology shows irregular dysplastic epidermis with hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis and cutaneous horn formation. Actinic (solar, senile) keratosis is a common slowly growing lesion that rarely develops on the eyelids. It typically affects e lderly, fair-skinned individuals on areas of sun-damaged skin

questions.text: Match the following benign pigmented lesions of the eyelid to their typical characteristics: Select the correct answer from the given below ciode:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

Highyeild:

Rare variants include kissing or split naevus that involves the upper and lower eyelid and may occasionally contain numerous hairs, and a very large lesion covering an extensive area of the body ('giant hairy naevus') . Large lesions have the potential for malignant transformation.

Random:

Explanation for all options:- Option: A. A freckle (Ephelis, plural Ephelides) is a small (generally 1-5 mm) brown macule due to increased melanin in the epidermal basal layer, typically in sun-exposed skin. The number of freckles varies with the level of sun exposure and can sometimes regress completely. Option: B Congenital naevi are uncommon and histologically resemble their acquired counterparts. They are usually small and of uniform colour. Option: C Junctional naevus occurs in young individuals as a uniformly brown macule or plaque. The naevus cells are located at the junction of the epidermis and dermis and have a low potential for malignant transformation . Option: D. Compound naevus occurs in middle age as a raised papular lesion The shade of pigment varies from light tan to dark brown but tends to be relatively uniform throughout. The naevus cells extend from the epidermis into the Dermis. It has a low malignant potential related to the junctional component.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-c,2-a,3-d,4-b

An isolated neurofibroma is common in normal individuals, but if multiple lesions are present, neurofibromatosis should be excluded.

Random:

Explanation for all options:- Option: A. Plexiform neurofibromas are typically present in childhood as a manifestation of neurofibromatosis type 1 with a characteristic S-shaped deformity of the upper eyelid. Cutaneous neurofibromas are benign nerve tumours, usually nodular or pedunculated, that can be found anywhere on the skin. Option: B. Pyogenic granuloma is a rapidly growing vascularized proliferation of granulation tissue that is usually antedated by surgery, trauma or infection, although some cases are idiopathic. Clinically there is a painful, rapidly growing, vascular granulating polypoidal lesion that may bleed following relatively trivial trauma. Option: C. Port-wine stain (naevus flammeus) is a congenital malformation of vessels within the superficial dermis, consisting histopathologically of vascular spaces of varying calibre separated by thin fibrous septa. About 10 per cent have associated ocular or CNS involvement, including Sturge-Weber and other defined syndromes. Option: D. Capillary haemangioma (strawberry naevus) is one of the most common tumours in infancy. It is three times as common in girls as in boys. Histopathology shows the proliferation of varying-sized vascular channels in the dermis and subcutaneous tissue.

questions.text: A 1-year-old female child was brought to you due to the presence of the lesion shown in the image below. The parents report that it was presented shortly after birth. They were worried that the presence of this lesion may affect the visual milestones of their child. The lesion blanches on pressure and swells on crying. The patient also has strawberry naevi on the thorax. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Capillary haemangioma The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Capillary haemangioma Capillary haemangioma (strawberry naevus) is one of the most common tumours in infancy. It is three times as common in girls as in boys. It presents shortly after birth as a unilateral, raised bright red lesion, usually in the upper lid. A deeper lesion appears purplish. The lesion blanches on pressure and may swell on crying. Ptosis is frequent and there may be an orbital extension.

Highyeild:

Occasionally the lesion may involve the skin of the face and some patients have strawberry naevi on other parts of the body.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Pilomatricoma (pilomatrixoma, calcifying epithelioma of Malherbe) is derived from the germinal matrix cells of the hair bulb and is the commonest hair follicle proliferation seen by ophthalmologists. It affects children and young adults and is more common in females . Histopathology shows irregular epithelial islands exhibiting viable basophilic cells at the periphery and degenerate shadow' cells centrally. Clinically it appears as a mobile purplish dermal nodule that may have a hard consistency due to calcification as seen in the Image. Calcification is frequently present and there is often a foreign body giant cell reaction . Malignant change is rare. The lesion is usually removed surgically. Option: C. Port-wine stain (naevus flammeus) is a congenital malformation of vessels within the superficial dermis, consisting histopathologically of vascular spaces of varying calibre separated by thin fibrous septa. About 10 per cent have associated ocular or CNS involvement, including Sturge-Weber and other defined syndromes. Ipsilateral glaucoma may be associated. Leptomeningeal haemangioma may occur as a part of Sturge-Weber It involves the ipsilateral parietal or occipital region and may cause contralateral focal or generalized seizures, hemiparesis or hemianopia. Ocular features may include ipsilateral glaucoma, episcleral haemangioma, iris heterochromia and diffuse choroidal haemangioma Darkening of the lesion to red or purple takes place with age and there is commonly associated soft tissue hypertrophy. Option: D. Plexiform neurofibromas are typically present in childhood as a manifestation of neurofibromatosis type 1 with a characteristic S-shaped deformity of the upper eyelid. Cutaneous neurofibromas are benign nerve tumours, usually nodular or pedunculated, that can be found anywhere on the skin. An isolated neurofibroma is common in normal individuals, but if multiple lesions are present, neurofibromatosis should be excluded.

Extraedge:

It is important to be aware of an association between multiple cutaneous lesions and visceral haemangiomas and to consider systemic assessment in appropriate cases.

questions.text: Match the below characteristics to the given conditions which predispose to eyelid malignancies: Select the correct answer from the given below ciode:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-a, 2-d, 3-c, 4-b

Highyeild:

Affected patients have a bird-like facial appearance and a significant propensity to the development of basal cell carcinoma (BCC), squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) and melanoma, which are commonly multiple. Conjunctival malignancies have also been reported.

Random:

Explanation for all options:- Young patients who suffer from one of the following conditions may develop eyelid malignancies. Option: A. Xeroderma pigmentosum is characterized by skin damage on exposure to sunlight, leading to progressive cutaneous abnormalities. More than 90 percent have ocular or periocular involvement and 65 percent experience photophobia. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive (AR) fashion. Option: B. Gorlin-Goltz syndrome (naevoid BCC syndrome) is a rare autosomal dominant (AD) disorder characterized by extensive congenital deformities of the eye, face, bone and central nervous system. Many patients develop multiple small BCC during the second decade of life and are also predisposed to medulloblastoma, breast carcinoma and Hodgkin lymphoma. Option: C. The Muir-Torre syndrome is a rare AD condition that predisposes to cutaneous and internal malignancies. Cutaneous tumours include BCC, sebaceous gland carcinoma and keratoacanthoma. Colorectal and genitourinary carcinomas are the most common systemic tumours. Option: D. Bazex syndrome can be used to describe two distinct conditions: Bazex-Dupré-Christol syndrome, an X-linked dominant condition characterized by multiple BCCs, commonly facial including the eyelids, associated with skin changes including follicular indentations without hairs on extensor surfaces (follicular atrophoderma) , hypohidrosis and hypotrichosis and Acrokeratosis paraneoplastica of Bazex , in which eczema-like and psoriasiform lesions are associated with an underlying malignancy of the upper respiratory or digestive tract.

questions.text: A 69-year-old male construction worker presented with the following lesion on the lower eyelid. On exam, you notice that this lesion is centrally ulcerated with pearly rolled edges. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Basal Cell Carcinoma The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) . BCC is the most common human malignancy and typically affects older individuals. The most important risk factors are fair skin, inability to tan and chronic exposure to sunlight. Ninety per cent of cases occur in the head and neck and about 10 percent of these involve the eyelid. BCC is by far the most common malignant eyelid tumors , accounting for 90 per cent of all cases.

Highyeild:

It most frequently arises from the lower eyelid, followed in relative frequency by the medial canthus, upper eyelid and lateral canthus.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is a much less common, but typically more aggressive tumour than BCC, with metastasis to regional lymph nodes in about 20 percent of cases. Histopathology shows dysplastic changes throughout the thickness of the epidermis. Careful surveillance of regional lymph nodes is therefore an important aspect of initial management. The tumour may also exhibit perineural spread to the intracranial cavity via the orbit Option: C. Sebaceous gland carcinoma (SGC) is a very rare, slowly growing tumour that most frequently affects the elderly, with a predisposition for females. It usually arises from the meibomian glands, although on occasion it may arise from the glands of Zeis or elsewhere. The pagetoid spread refers to the extension of a tumour within the epithelium and is not uncommon. Option: D. Keratoacanthoma is a rare, rapidly growing but subsequently regressing tumour that usually occurs in fair-skinned individuals with a history of chronic sun exposure. Immunosuppressive therapy is also a predisposing factor. Invasion and metastasis are rare. A pink dome-shaped hyperkeratotic lesion develops, often on the lower lid and may double or treble in size within weeks.

Extraedge:

The Image shows a lesion that is centrally ulcerated with pearly raised rolled edges and dilated and irregular blood vessels (telangiectasis) over its lateral margins With time it may erode a large portion of the eyelid.

Ninety per cent of cases occur in the head and neck and about 10 percent of these involve the eyelid. BCC is by far the most common malignant eyelid tumor , accounting for 90 per cent of all cases.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Gorlin-Goltz syndrome (naevoid BCC syndrome) is a rare autosomal dominant (AD) disorder characterized by extensive congenital deformities of the eye, face, bone and central nervous system. Many patients develop multiple small BCC during the second decade of life. Option: C. Sclerosing (morphoeic) BCC is less common and may be difficult to diagnose because it infiltrates laterally beneath the epidermis as an indurated plaque. questions.text: For the treatment of malignant lesions of eyelids, removal via surgical treatment followed by reconstruction may be warranted. Which of these statements about the reconstruction is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: Defects involving less than one-third of the eyelid can be closed directly

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior lamellar defects may be closed directly

options.label: C
options.text: Moderate-size defects require a Tenzel semicircular flap (e.g.) for closure

options.label: D
options.text: In the Hughes tarso conjunctival approach the wound edges are approximated as far as possible and the defect is allowed to granulate and heal by secondary intention.

questions.correct_answer: D. In the Hughes tarso conjunctival approach the wound edges are approximated as far as possible and the defect is allowed to granulate and heal by secondary intention.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In the Hughes tarso conjunctival approach the wound edges are approximated as far as possible and the defect is allowed to granulate and heal by secondary intention. The technique of reconstruction depends on the extent of tissue removed. It is important to reconstruct both anterior and posterior lamellae, each of which must be reconstructed with similar tissue. Full reconstruction of the defect created by tumour removal may not always be required.

Highyeild:

In the laissez-faire approach , the wound edges are approximated as far as possible and the defect is allowed to granulate and heal by secondary intention. Even large defects can often achieve a satisfactory outcome with time.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Small defects involving less than one-third of the eyelid can usually be closed directly, provided the surrounding tissue is sufficiently elastic to allow approximation of the cut edges If necessary, a lateral cantholysis can be performed for increased mobilization. Option: B. Anterior lamellar defects may be closed directly or with a local flap or skin graft. Option: C. Moderate-size defects involving up to half of the eyelid may require a flap (e.g. Tenzel semicircular) for closure

Clinically a pink, red-violet to brown lesion develops, which may be mistaken for a haematoma or naevus. Treatment is by radiotherapy or excision and by optimal control of AIDS . Option: B. BCC is the most common human malignancy and typically affects older individuals. The most important risk factors are fair skin, inability to tan and chronic exposure to sunlight. Ninety per cent of cases occur in the head and neck and about 10 percent of these involve the eyelid. BCC is by far the most common malignant eyelid tumour , accounting for 90 per cent of all cases. It most frequently arises from the lower eyelid, followed in relative frequency by the medial canthus, upper eyelid and lateral canthus. Option: C. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is a much less common, but typically more aggressive tumour than BCC, with metastasis to regional lymph nodes in about 20 percent of cases. Histopathology shows dysplastic changes throughout the thickness of the epidermis. Careful surveillance of regional lymph nodes is therefore an important aspect of initial management. The tumour may also exhibit perineural spread to the intracranial cavity via the orbit .

Extraedge:

Nodular melanoma is typically a blue-black nodule surrounded by normal skin. Treatment is usually by wide excision and may include local lymph node removal.

Option: B Congenital naevi are uncommon and histologically resemble their acquired counterparts. They are usually small and of uniform colour. Rare variants include kissing or split naevus that involves the upper and lower eyelid and may occasionally contain numerous hairs. Option: C. Xanthelasma is a common, frequently bilateral condition typically affecting middle-aged and elderly individuals. Hyperlipidaemia is found in about one-third of patients, in whom corneal arcus may also be present. In contrast to a chalazion, fat in xanthelasma is mainly intracellular, with lipid-laden histiocytes (foam cells) in the dermis .

Highyeild:

Xanthelasma are yellowish subcutaneous plaques, usually in the medial aspects of the eyelids, commonly bilateral and are multiple.

Extraedge:

Recurrence occurs in up to 50 per cent and is most common in patients with hypercholesterolaemia. Simple excision is commonly performed where adequate excess skin is present. Microdissection: Larger lesions can be raised in a flap, the fatty deposits dissected from overlying skin under a surgical microscope using micro scissors and the skin replaced
